Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: STS Forum on Fukishima: Building a Transnational Research Agenda and Strategy for Engagement through a Social Scientific Understanding of Disasters & Disaster Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Disaster science is emerging as distinctive field that incorporates a range of scientific disciplines, and has implications for many aspects of disaster governance. This workshop investigates the social, technical and organizational factors that contribute to or limit disasters, disaster mitigation, and the remediation and recovery efforts that follow major disasters. To address these issues, Japan- and US-based participants use the Fukushima nuclear accident and the closely related disasters that affected Eastern Japan in 2011 to develop new knowledge, making explicit comparisons to Chernobyl, the 1995 Kobe Earthquake, September 11th, Hurricane Katrina and the Kanto Dai Shinsai disaster. Science and Technology Studies theories of epistemic cultures, scientific and disciplinary fields, public and institutional responses to crises, and the relationship between embedded research and policy engagement are used to address key workshop questions.

Outcomes include a NSF Workshop Report that lays out major new directions in social scientific studies of disaster, the creation of a transnational network of disaster science researchers with deeper expertise in the intersection of social and technical aspects of disaster, and web site distribution of conference papers and materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the project were to assemble an international community of scholars investigating the 2011 East Japan Disaster, with the aim of giving articulation to an emerging field of Disaster Science and Technology Studies (Disaster STS). A highly successful workshop was held at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory adjoining the University of California Berkeley campus as hosted by the Center for Science, Technology, Medicine, and Society. A total of 34 participants attended the event, with representatives from over a half-dozen different countries including Japan. A total of 23 papers, 3 plenary lectures, and one keynote lecture were included in the program. Pulications emerging out of this conversation include a 2014 special issue of Japan Focus on the 3.11 East Japan Disaster; an edited compilation with the University of Pennsylvania Press, in preparation, based on papers presented at the workshop and events held in preparation for the workshop; and an online forum (http://fukushimaforum.wordpress.com/) for researchers interested in studying the 3.11 East Japan Disaster from an STS perspective. The online forum continues to host the pre-publication manuscripts that were distributed in advance of the workshop, including public commentary that were collected for these manuscripts. The research network that we assembled continued to persist and serve as an important vehicle for scholarly communication bewteen the scholars studying this topic, and the broader area of Disaster STS.
